instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A - PMIC?
threads.message:
Liquid damage with slight corrosion around <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3500</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>. So slight that I thought brushing it off with alcohol would be enough to bring it back to life. Rest of the board looks mint. 

No traces or pads corroded but I did replaced <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>, <CHIP>U3500</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> asa precaution with no change. 

Taking 20V @ 0A. Cant see any shorts around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>.

<CHIP>U7650</CHIP> voltages are as follows:

Pin 1: 0V
Pin 2 (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>): 0V
Pin 3: 0V
Pin 4 (<SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL>): 0V
Pin 12 (<SIGNAL>P5VXX_EN</SIGNAL>): 0V
Pin 20 (<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>): 0V
Pin 21 (<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL>): 0V 
Pin 29 (<SIGNAL>P5V5_S5</SIGNAL>): 0V

Diode mode and resistance to ground:
L7670: 0.407V 900 Ω
L7690: 0.353V 780 Ω 

Diode mode at <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> is 0.410V

<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>: 3.1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_LDO3V</SIGNAL>: 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_VREF</SIGNAL>: 1.23V
<SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>: 3.4V

On this board, <RESISTOR>R7828</RESISTOR> is the one present and reads 100kΩ 

PMIC issue??? Any help would be appreciated. Thanks in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A - PMIC?
threads.message:
Exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?

Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL>.
If low, change <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
You can solder 10-47K in place of <RESISTOR>R7828</RESISTOR>, without problems.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A - PMIC?
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 13.04V

0.462V in diode mode on <SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL>

<RESISTOR>R7828</RESISTOR> reads 100kΩ, still swap this out for a 10-47k?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A - PMIC?
threads.message:
Yes, try forcing the signal.
If still low, bad PMIC...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A - PMIC?
threads.message: Awesome. Will try this shortly and report back. thanks again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A - PMIC?
threads.message: Even with forcing the signal with 10k resistor (<SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V), No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> or anything around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>. Guess i need to get a PMIC stencil...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A - PMIC?
threads.message: Swapped the PMIC (twice, from 2 different donors) and no change either time. Starting to lose hope with this one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A - PMIC?
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A - PMIC?
threads.message: I didn'd replace the resistor back to original (still the 10k I put in there). I will swap it out and report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A - PMIC?
threads.message: noticed a short on s5 with new PCIM, fixed the short, plugged in charger, and PCH released smoke. Thanks for your help and optimism.
